Award.AwardTitle: Colloids in molten inorganic salts and liquid metals
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The colloidal state is ubiquitous in biology, chemistry, and materials science. It offers a general way to create macroscopically homogeneous combinations of highly dissimilar components, such as milk consisting of immiscible fat and water. Stabilizing the colloidal state in different systems is at the heart of many technological processes. This project is focused on a novel class of colloidal systems. Preliminary studies show that a colloidal state can be realized for different nanoparticles in molten inorganic salt and, probably, in liquid metals. Liquid metals and molten salts are widely used in metallurgy and soldering, as heat transfer fluids in thermal solar technologies, and other important areas. Demonstrating stable colloidal systems in such media and understanding the factors that govern stability may open up opportunities to design new types of composites using a rich toolbox of techniques from colloidal chemistry. A comprehensive education and outreach program accompanies this research and focuses on education enrichment for the underrepresented African-American and Hispanic K-12 populations on Chicago's South Side. This project supports the continued development and distribution of nanoscience educational resources for the U. Chicago chemistry community as well as for K-12 students. This includes the development of a new graduate materials chemistry track at the University of Chicago and a continued successful effort to help undergraduates and high school students gain research experience.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This project is directly relevant to the development of new colloidal systems. Nanoparticles of various transition metals, semiconductors, rare-earth, and magnetic materials form stable colloidal dispersions in various molten salts and liquid metals. The colloidal stability of nanoparticles in these media cannot be explained by traditional stabilization mechanisms. It appears that neither electrostatic nor steric repulsion can explain colloidal stability in a molten ionic salt. Given the very high charge density, electrostatic potential is screened on the sub-nm distance, making electrostatic repulsion short-ranged and inferior compared to van der Waals attraction. The absence of brush-like species at the particle surface in molten salt also rules out the possibility of classical steric stabilization. This project incorporates systematic experimental and theoretical investigations of this class of functional nanomaterials that are colloidally stabilized in molten inorganic salts and liquid metals. Specific aims of this project include the study and development of an understanding of the colloidal stabilization mechanism in molten salts and liquid metals at elevated temperatures, as well as exploration of properties and potential applications for colloidal dispersions of nanomaterials in molten salts and liquid metals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
If two components do not mix at the molecular level, they still can be homogenized in form of a colloidal solution where particles or droplets of one compound are dispersed in the second phase, a solvent. For example, cow?s milk is a colloid of fat droplets in water.

With support from NSF grant DMR-1611371, the Talapin group discovered that stable colloids can exist not only in water and other "conventional" solvents but also in molten salts, such as molten NaCl at elevated temperatures. This observation expands a century-old concept of colloidal solution and creates opportunities for design of novel functional materials.

This project investigated the phenomenon of colloidal stability in molten inorganic salts and developed techniques for preparation, handling, and analysis of low-dimensional materials in molten inorganic salts. Our results suggest that molten salts have the potential to revolutionize synthesis of low-dimensional functional materials by scalable solution methods. Inorganic molten salts bring unmatched thermal stability, chemical inertness, high polarizability, and other characteristics.

The scientific activities supported by this grant include: (1) first demonstration of stable colloids in molten inorganic salts, (2) demonstration of novel colloidal chemistry in molten salts: first synthesis of luminescent In1‑xGaxP and In1-xGaxAs Quantum Dots, (3) investigation of defects in colloidal GaAs Quantum Dots and using molten-salt annealing for curing structural defects in colloidal GaAs Quantum Dots, and (4) understanding contributions from structural and electronic disorder in colloidal InP Quantum Dots to their emission spectra, (5) theoretical description of screening in dense ionic fluids with a charge-frustrated Ising model, and (6) experimental insights in solvent restructuring and colloidal stability of NCs in molten inorganic salts.

The unique properties of molten inorganic salts were used to synthesize novel technologically important nanomaterials.  With support from this NSF grant, the Talapin group demonstrated cation exchange reactions on pre-synthesized InP and InAs Nanocrystals to form In1-xGaxP and In1-xGaxAs Quantum Dots at temperatures above 400?C. This approach produced novel ternary alloy Quantum Dots with controllable compositions that showed size- and composition-dependent absorption and emission spectra. These semiconductors are technologically important for displays and solid-state lighting, but have not been synthesized in solution-processed, colloidal form.

In parallel, the team investigated the interactions between nanoscale objects immersed in molten metals. They found that the previously accepted theoretical description of van der Waals forces in liquid metals underestimated the attractive force by a factor of 100. An advanced theoretical description corrected this error and obtained results in a good agreement with experimental data. The team of researchers achieved a uniform distribution of nanoscale ceramic particles in liquid metals through the colloidal gelation, where particles formed self-supporting networks stable against macroscopic segregation. This network acted as a reinforcement boosting mechanical properties of the resulting metal-matrix composites.

This project helped continue interdisciplinary training in science and engineering with focuses on synthesis and characterization of nanoscale materials, and development of electronic and optoelectronic devices. This NSF award supported the training of eight graduate students, and three undergraduate students, and resulted in five PhD theses. The undergraduate students supported by this award belong to underrepresented or minority groups.

Additionally, under this project, we have continued to develop an outreach program that promotes science education and awareness to inner-city student populations. Our initiatives focused on hands-on science experiences that develop critical thinking, problem solving, and other fundamental investigative skills. Graduate student engagement in outreach activities teaches them to communicate complex research material to diverse audiences of various levels of education. The research team working on this project has been actively involved in educational outreach activities through the ?Physics with a Bang? science fair at the University of Chicago. Furthermore, the team has also been leading science clubs after school sessions and science night events at Chicago Southside public schools that have high enrollments of minorities and economically disadvantaged students. Three recent partner schools include Murray Language Academy, Woodson South, and Langston Hughes Elementary. These activities effectively reach both adults and students in underrepresented minority neighborhoods on the South and Southwest sides of Chicago and promote their pursuit of careers in science and engineering. In the last three years, the research team has focused on introducing new activities that emphasize the basic chemistry behind materials research: materials composition, strength, and elasticity; and mixture reactions and density.
